bestBHT.bht: The significance of settling debts is highlighted in this teaching, echoing the concept found in Matthew and the reference to the last mite. The phrase till thou have paid underscores the importance of fully repaying what is owed, even if it is a small amount. This aligns with the examples of the poor widow's mite mentioned elsewhere, emphasizing the value of our actions, regardless of their size, in the sight of God.

Henry Alford: 59.] See on Matt. v. 25, and, on the word mite, Mark xii. 42.
Philip Schaff: Those who come unreleased before the Judge at the last day, will be punished forever.
This figure represents the danger of punishment in view of failure to know and do what is right.
Mite. Greek, 'lepton,' the smallest of coins then in use.
Archibald T. Robertson: Till thou have paid (εως αποδωις). Second aorist active subjunctive of αποδιδωμ, to pay back in full."
The last mite (το εσχατον λεπτον). From λεπω, to peel off the bark. Very small brass coin, one-eighth of an ounce."
In the N.T. only here and Luke 21:2; Mark 12:42 (the poor widow's mite) which see.
John Gill: till thou hast paid the very last mite...
John Wesley: A mite — was about the third part of a farthing sterling.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus teaches in Luke 12:59 that we must settle our debts before the Judge, just as we see in Matthew 5:25. The phrase till thou have paid emphasizes the importance of paying back in full. The mention of the last mite refers to a small brass coin, which highlights the significance of even the smallest contributions. This concept of settling debts and the significance of even the smallest actions aligns with the teachings of Luke 21:2 and Mark 12:42, where the poor widow's mite is mentioned. Through this verse, Jesus reminds us that our actions, no matter how small, matter in the eyes of God.

The importance of settling debts is emphasized in this teaching, drawing parallels to the concept in Matthew and the mention of the last mite. The phrase till thou have paid emphasizes the significance of paying back in full, even the smallest contributions. This aligns with the examples of the poor widow's mite mentioned in other passages, highlighting the importance of our actions, regardless of their size, in the eyes of God.

Jesus reminds us about the importance of settling our debts in this teaching, resonating with the concept in Matthew and the mention of the last mite. The phrase till thou have paid emphasizes the necessity of repaying in full, even if it is a small amount. This aligns with the examples of the poor widow's mite referenced in other passages, underscoring the significance of our actions, regardless of their magnitude, in the eyes of God.

Through Jesus' teaching in this passage, the significance of repaying debts is emphasized, reflecting the parallel concept mentioned in Matthew and the inclusion of the last mite. The phrase till thou have paid underscores the importance of fully settling obligations, even if they are small. This idea aligns with the mention of the poor widow's mite in other references, highlighting the value of our actions, regardless of their magnitude, in God's perspective.
